 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on additional financing 
of  up  to  $100,000,000  for  guarantee  and  unfunded  risk  participation  products  offered  by  the 
Microfinance  Risk  Participation  and  Guarantee  Program  to  support  (i)  expansion  into  new 
countries  and  (ii)  a  major  change  in  scope  to  broaden  product  offerings  and  facilitate  market 
innovation.  The  major  change  in  scope  entails  (i)  changes  in  the  eligibility  criteria  for  partner 
financial institutions (PFIs), (ii) expansion of the products to be guaranteed and/or risk participated 
on an unfunded basis, and (iii) extension of the permissible tenor of the credit enhancement of 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) under the program to a maximum of 5 years. 
 

II. 

THE PROGRAM 

Background 

 
A. 
 
2. 
Globally, about 2 billion low-income adults lack access to finance and are excluded from 
the  formal  finance  sector.1  Lower-income  people  find  it  difficult  to  borrow  from  formal  lending 
sources  for  various  reasons,  including  small  loan  amounts,  lack  of  proper  identification,  and 
absence of a credit history and collateral. Microfinance has been a critical tool in addressing this 
market gap and reducing poverty by providing financial services to low-income people, particularly 
women. However, microfinance institutions (MFIs) and other institutions that cater to this market 
segment struggle to obtain sufficient commercial funding, particularly in local currency, to meet 
the demands of their clients. 
 
To  address this  market gap,  in 2010  the  ADB  Board of  Directors  approved  up  to $250 
3. 
million to support the microfinance sector in ADB developing member countries (DMCs) through 
the program,2 which is implemented through unfunded risk participations and guarantees. PFIs 
provide local currency loans, with a maximum tenor of 3 years, to ADB-approved MFIs in ADB 
DMCs, thereby catalyzing private sector participation and mobilizing additional funds for the MFIs 
to onlend to low-income populations.3 The program onboarded the first PFI in 2012. As of June 
2017, the program has accredited two global financial institutions (Standard Chartered Bank and 
Citibank NA) and four local Indian institutions (IFMR Capital Finance Private Limited, RBL Bank 
Limited, Kotak Mahindra Bank Limited, and IndusInd Bank Limited). 
 
4. 
The program currently supports 20 MFIs in Bangladesh, India, and Indonesia. Based on 
the outstanding portfolio as of June 2017, 75% of exposure is in India, which has large unmet 
demand for access to finance and a favorable operating environment. Based on the program’s 
success  and  increased  market  demand,  on  26  October  2015  the  ADB  Board  of  Directors  (i) 
removed the program’s expiration date, thus including it in ADB’s mainstream operations; and (ii) 
increased the overall limit to $240 million.4 Key achievements are summarized in the table.

5. 
One  of  the  program’s  strongest  attributes  is  its  ability  to  support  MFIs  through  various 
stages of growth. ADB implemented the program in India shortly after the 2010 Andhra Pradesh 
microfinance  crisis,  which  tightened  market  liquidity.5  Importantly,  the  program  mobilized 
commercial  financing  during  this  critical  period  by  sharing  credit  risk.  Since  2010,  and  with 
substantial improvements in regulation in India and the introduction of financial inclusion policies 
some MFIs have grown significantly, and are now converting into small finance banks and exiting 
the program. Several of these larger MFIs and small finance banks are now being funded directly 
by ADB outside of the program through long-term debt and equity.6 Given these developments, 
the program has shifted to supporting small and medium-sized MFIs that cover more differentiated 
and unbanked locations in India. Although Bangladesh’s microfinance sector is large, and there 
is  considerable  unmet  demand  for  financing,  program  implementation  has  been  slower  than 
expected.  ADB  is  addressing  MFI  needs through  one  PFI  and  seeking opportunities to further 
expand the program. Program implementation has also proven to be challenging in Indonesia, 
given  the  fragmented  market  composed  of  various  rural  banks,  a  few  large  microfinance 
institutions, and small cooperatives. Program PFIs have been selective in providing MFI loans, 
with  low  exposure  to  date.  Given  market  dynamics,  it  is  unclear  if  exposure  will  increase 
significantly. 
 
B. 
 
6. 
Several lessons have emerged from the program’s operational period and observations 
of  market  evolution  and  innovation,  particularly  in  India.  Knowledge  gained  since  program 
inception and from the performance of the MFIs involved in the program indicates that while the 
program structure performed well in markets such as India, innovating and expanding to other 
markets with differing levels of maturity will require applying other strategies and structures. 
 
7. 
Key  market  developments.  The  microfinance  sector  across  Asia  and  the  Pacific  is 
diverse with differing levels of maturity. Different types of institutions provide financial services to 
low-income people,  including  nongovernment  organizations,  MFIs,  and banks.7  In India,  larger 
MFIs  are  starting  to  access  capital  markets,  with  credit  enhancements  to  improve  ratings  and 

Lessons  

                                                
5   Andhra Pradesh was a microfinance pioneer in India and the largest Indian MFI market in 2010. Rapid market growth 
and rising borrower over-indebtedness preceded the crisis. Concerns about the ability of low-income borrowers to 
service  mounting  debts  led  the  state  government  to  introduce  the  Andhra  Pradesh  Microfinance  Institutions 
(Regulation of Money Lending) Bill in October 2010, which affected the collection of existing loans by  MFIs. The 
Andhra Pradesh crisis led to several regulatory reforms and operational improvements.

2 

 

 3 

lower risks for investors, as they seek to diversify their funding options.8  But smaller MFIs still 
need  access  to  standard  wholesale  commercial  financing.  ADB  can  play  an  important  role  in 
supporting some of these small, newer MFIs.  In contrast to MFIs in Myanmar, where the sector 
is still nascent, MFIs struggle to receive even basic term loan facilities. MFIs in some countries 
now provide a range of financial products—with longer tenors—to meet the changing demands 
of  micro  borrowers  for  housing,  agriculture,  microenterprise,  green  finance,  9  and  savings  and 
insurance. There has been a shift from joint liability group lending to individual lending products 
that are often collateralized and have larger loan sizes, which is a typical sign of maturing clients.10 
In Bangladesh, for instance, individuals and micro and small enterprises now comprise about 25% 
of the total portfolios, indicating a clear shift in lending models. There has also been growth in 
microfinance lending through banks due to revised strategies or government requirements (e.g., 
in India).11   
 
8. 
Key operational lessons. ADB program parameters need to be broadened to address 
the changing landscape, including (i) new product structures that would enable ADB to support 
MFIs without PFIs and (ii) an increase in tenor. 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

The Assistance 

 
A. 
 
9. 
The assistance consists of (i) additional financing to raise the program limit by up to $100 
million to $340 million and (ii) an expansion in program scope (para. 1). This will support, at any 
time  and  on  a  revolving  basis,  up  to  $680  million  of  outstanding  loans  to  low-income  groups, 
assuming ADB guarantees the default risk of up to 50% of the exposure on PFIs and/or MFIs.12 
 
B. 
 

Proposed Additional Financing and Change in Scope 

1. 

Additional Financing 

 
10. 
PFI limits are linked to the overall program limit, and provision of additional financing of up 
to $100 million as proposed in the change in scope will enable accreditation of more PFIs and 
support program growth and expansion. Access to financial services remains problematic across 
most ADB DMCs. Despite rapid progress in the rate of financial inclusion in markets such as India, 
the  demand  for  financing  throughout  the  region  remains  vast,  especially  for  local  currency 
financing.13  The  estimated  annual  demand for  households in  Indian  rural  and  urban areas, for

 example, is $36 billion.14 Bangladesh estimates a yearly unmet demand of $5 billion, Pakistan a 
demand of $3 billion until 2020, and in Myanmar, a yearly demand of at least $1 billion (footnote 
8). This is evidenced by the low percentage of the population that has accessed credit through 
formal channels in India (approximately 15.71% of men and 11.42% of women), or has borrowed 
money from a financial institution (9.8% women and 10% men, in Bangladesh, 11.8% of women 
and 19.5% of men in Myanmar, and 0.3% of women and 2.6% of men in Pakistan).15 The program 
will expand to countries with clear unmet financing demand and interest from PFIs to provide local 
currency  loans  to  MFIs.  Further  considerations  for  country  expansion  are  the  size  and 
performance of the microfinance sector, and the existence of a supportive enabling environment 
(regulatory and ancillary institutions). Target markets in the near to midterm include Myanmar, 
Pakistan, and Sri Lanka. 
 

2. 

Change in Scope 

 
11. 
Partner  financial  institution  eligibility  criteria.  The  types  of  financial  institutions  that 
provide financing to MFIs has expanded and the entities have established track records. Changes 
to the PFI eligibility criteria are needed to include nonbank financial institutions and other licensed 
institutions that have (i) at least 5 years of experience in lending to MFIs and (ii) a loan portfolio 
of at least $250 million. 
 
12. 

Expansion of guarantee and risk participation products to include:  

(i) 

 
Guarantee  and/or  risk  participation  in  a  partner  financial  institution’s 
microfinance  portfolio.  ADB  guarantees  or  participates  in  the  default  risk  of  a 
PFI’s wholesale lending to a particular MFI and establishes a credit limit for each 
participating  MFI.  However,  in  some  countries  (e.g.,  India)  loans  of  microfinance 
borrowers  (which  are  often  originated  by  MFIs  used  as  agents)  are  pooled.16 
Existing and potential new PFI and MFI program partners have requested that ADB 
guarantee or participate in these pooled microfinance loans. It is proposed that ADB 
partially guarantee or risk participate in up to 50% of pooled microfinance loans on 
the balance sheet of a PFI, thus reducing the risk profile of those assets for the PFI 
and encouraging further lending to the sector. This portfolio guarantee and/or risk 
participation  will  be  done  on  a  pilot  basis  with  existing  accredited  PFIs  and  is 
expected to be used initially in India.17  
 

(ii)  Guarantee  and/or  risk  participation  directly  to  microfinance  institutions 
without the participation of a partner financial institution. For countries where 
ADB  does  not  have  an  accredited  PFI,  it  is  proposed  that  a  stand-alone  partial 
guarantee  and/or  risk  participation  for  approved  MFIs  be  incorporated  into  the 
program so that MFIs could obtain a bank loan. ADB would share up to 50% of the

(iii)  Guarantee and/or risk participation for capital market instruments issued by 
microfinance institutions. The program has successfully nurtured smaller MFIs, 
as  illustrated  in  several  instances  in  India.  Medium-sized  MFIs  are  expected  to 
access the capital markets to reduce their dependency on commercial borrowing, 
and  most  if  not  all  will  find  it  challenging  to  execute  transactions,  such  as  local 
currency  bond  issuances  or  securitizations,  as  a  result  of  a  lack  of  or  low  credit 
ratings.  To  address  this  situation,  ADB  would  offer  partial  credit  guarantees  on 
bonds issued by MFIs through a debenture trustee and on securitizations to support 
MFI access to diversified funding in the capital markets. 

(a) 

(b) 

 
Bond issuance. For bond issuances, 18 ADB would take credit exposure 
on the MFI issuing the bond. Under the proposed change in scope, ADB 
would initially cooperate with a known arranger  or co-guarantor, such as 
IFMR Capital,19 and guarantee up to 50% of the principal bond amount.20 
Bond  issuances  typically  have  a  tenor  of  3–5  years,  and  ADB’s  credit

Securitization.  For  securitizations—where  a  pool  of  microfinance  loans 
will be sold without recourse to investors22—under the proposed change in 
scope ADB would partially guarantee and/or risk participate in the junior or

accredited PFI. This option would require that ADB guarantee and/or risk

portfolio guarantee. 

 
13. 
ADB will not take the first-loss position when providing the partial credit guarantees or risk 
participations in these instruments. Demand for partial credit guarantees is largely in India, but 
these offerings could be expanded elsewhere as capital markets develop in the region. 
 
14. 
Extension of tenor to up to 5 years. Under the proposed change in scope, the maximum 
loan  tenor  that  ADB  will  guarantee  or  risk  participate  in would  be  extended from  3  to  5  years.

and bond issuances, with a tenor of 5 years. ADB will limit exposure above 3 to 5 years to not

C. 
 
15. 
Under  the  existing  program,  ADB  signs  risk  participation  and  partial  credit  guarantee 
agreements  with  accredited  PFIs.  PFIs  are  selected  against  approved  criteria  and  follow  a 
prescribed accreditation and due diligence process. After onboarding the MFIs and determining 
the respective approval limit, ADB participates in the credit risk of the loan by the PFIs to MFIs, 
up to the agreed limit.23 The following processes would apply to the suggested changes to the 
guarantees and risk participation products: 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

 
Portfolio guarantee. ADB will establish a separate obligor limit for an accredited 
PFI to guarantee part of its microfinance portfolio, and establish a portfolio limit for 
this specific structure under the PFI limit, with any losses shared between the PFI 
and ADB. 
Bond  issuance.  The  existing  accreditation,  onboarding,  and  limit  approval 
process will also apply to the credit enhancements of MFI bond issuances. ADB 
will work with an experienced arranger or the PFI; depending on the structure, the 
risk may be shared between the PFI and ADB, with ADB guaranteeing up to 50% 
of the bond issuance. ADB will work only with experienced arrangers. 
Securitization. To partially guarantee junior or senior notes  under a securitization 
structure, ADB will establish a portfolio limit for this specific structure under the MFI 
umbrella or PFI limit, with any losses shared between the PFI and ADB. ADB will 
also work with an arranger. 

 
16. 
As one MFI may avail of several guarantee types, ADB will establish an umbrella limit for 
each MFI for better monitoring. The program team will monitor the limits established with respect 
to the proposed new products, the umbrella limit, and the allocation. 
 
17. 
Reporting  and  monitoring  arrangements.  The  terms  of  the  risk  participation  or 
guarantee agreements with a PFI, an MFI, or a bond issuer will require the PFI, the MFI, or the 
bond  issuer  to  submit  financial  and  other  reports  at  predetermined  regular  intervals  and  as 
requested,  including  (i)  annual  review  reports  with  audited  financial  statements;  (ii)  quarterly 
compliance  certificates  for  financial  covenants  or  operational  highlights,  if  requested;  and  (iii) 
quarterly reporting on the microfinance loan portfolios. ADB will conduct an annual review of the 
PFIs and the MFIs under the program following the relevant staff instruction, and will monitor the 
use of limits by each PFI and MFI monthly. 
 
18. 
Resource requirements. The expansion will require additional resources to handle the 
expansion  with  increase  in  volume  and  monitoring,  with  specific  expertise  required  for  certain 
aspects  of  capital  market  transactions.  A  separate  technical  assistance  (TA)  program  will  be 
prepared to provide the required consulting inputs, with an estimated cost of up to $1 million over 
a 3-year period. 
 
D. 
 
19. 
Support  access  to  finance  for  low-income  and  women  borrowers.  There  is  a 
significant gap  in the  supply  of  and demand for financial  services for  people with  low-incomes

6 

 

 7 

(para  10),  including  financial  products  for  income-generating  activities,  low-cost  affordable 
housing,  and green finance. Through  broadened  parameters  of the  program,  ADB  will  support 
new financial products aimed at the bottom of the pyramid segment. Women are one of the most 
vulnerable groups in the world’s poorest populations, and a significant number remain unbanked. 
The  program  will  continue  to  support  MFIs  and  their  clients,  most  of  whom  are  women,  and 
continue  a  TA  program  for  Indian  MFIs  on  responsible  finance  practices,  including  gender-
focused  consumer  protection  principles.24  Under  a  new  TA  program,  which  will  be  approved 
separately, ADB will work with PFIs and/or MFIs to provide gender-focused activities, including 
financial literacy training and implementation of gender-focused policies. 
 
20. 
Provide  access  to  local  currency  and  support  capital  markets  development. 
Commercial banks are often not comfortable or familiar with this asset class, and their strategies 
do not include catering to this lower-income market segment. Many MFIs in other DMCs are much 
smaller  and  less  mature  than  those  in  India.  Banks  often  face  restrictions  on  capital  and 
counterparty  lines  that  limit  their  possible  lending  volumes  to  MFIs.  The  program  can  help 
overcome these limitations and will continue to expand its operations into new countries, making 
additional local currency lending available to MFIs, which will in turn increase access to finance 
for low-income populations. 
 
21. 
The program will also support growth of capital markets and familiarity with the MFI asset 
class. Diversified funding sources are essential for MFIs, which are usually restricted from taking 
deposits. Most capital markets in ADB DMCs lack depth and are illiquid beyond the highest-rated 
issuances. ADB’s credit enhancement will facilitate issuance of capital markets instruments by 
MFIs and widen the set of investors, particularly from the private sector. 
 
22. 
Catalyze private sector financing. Through ADB’s partial guarantee or risk participation, 
private  sector  involvement  in  microfinance  sector  financing  has  been  and  will  continue  to  be 
facilitated.  The  growth  of  the  microfinance  sector  has  generated  increased  interest  from  more 
private sector financial institutions, but risk sharing through multiple product structures is needed 
to encourage their entry into and growth in the sector.

23. 
The  2010  report  and  recommendation  of  the  President  and  the  2015  major  change  in 
scope  and  additional  financing  for  this  program  addressed  key  risk  issues,  such  as  the 
creditworthiness  of  the  underlying  MFIs  and  their  loan  portfolio,  the  performance  and  credit 
underwriting skills of the PFIs, regulatory and reputation risk, geographical concentration risks, 
foreign currency risk. The proposed changes do not aim to dilute the principles of (i) working with 
PFIs  or  other  partners  that  have  capital  exposed  in  the  same  transactions  as  ADB,  and  have 
interests  aligned  with  ADB;  and  (ii)  partnering with  institutions  with  on-the-ground  capability  to 
monitor MFIs, and augment ADB’s due diligence capability and quality. The identified risks remain 
valid but have been updated, for example foreign currency risk as guaranteed loans, bonds, or 
other instruments are denominated in local currency and if an MFI defaults, ADB will be liable to 
pay in United States dollars or local currency (if available). When a claim is paid in dollars, ADB 
will continue to have a claim in local currency under the original guaranteed loan, bond or other 
instruments.  The  2010  Board  approval  allowed  this  to  reduce  the  financing  cost  for  MFIs  by 
eliminating foreign exchange hedging costs (footnote 2).

financial products for different purposes. 
 
26. 
Outcome.  Sustainable financial  inclusion  increased.  Through  a  combination  of  funding 
instruments, partners will receive more financing for lending to the target population, and PFIs will 
be more comfortable to lend directly to this market segment. Success in achieving the outcome 
will be measured in terms of the increase in partners’ loan portfolios, maintenance of the average 
nonperforming loan ratio, the increase in the aggregate number of ultimate borrowers. 
 
27.

be measured based on the increase in ADB’s guarantee and risk participation volume and the 
expansion of the program to two more countries.
